In the meantime, remote learning will continue for CCPS students. Parents are strongly encouraged to contact their child’s teacher should they have any issues.

post_text: Charlotte County Public Schools is excited to announce the implementation of the Community Eligibility Provision (CEP) through the National School Lunch and School Breakfast Program. Due to an increased number of directly certified students, all enrolled students will be provided a healthy breakfast and lunch at no charge each day of the 2020-2021 school year. Our continued participation with the CEP program will be evaluated at the end of the school year to determine if it will continue into the future. It’s very important for all enrolled students to participate in both breakfast and lunch every day to ensure that CCPS can continue to offer this program! In the coming days, more information regarding the feeding program will be provided on the CCPS website and division Facebook page.

Ms. Toombs is a Math Teacher at R-H. Today she is teaching us Distributive Property and Factoring by GCF. Thank you Ms. Toombs!
Ms. Toombs had this to say, "I am sharing a video to help some students with their Algebra skills. In Algebra, we work on the distributive property to multiply monomials to polynomials and polynomials to polynomials. In another unit, we learn to undo the distributive property which we call factoring. In this video, I take a monomial (1 term) and multiply it to a binomial (2 terms), then I factor by taking out the GCF (monomial). This example shows the multiplication and then the opposite which is like division by taking out the monomial the two terms have in common. I hope this helps better understand the skills we have learned!"

On Thursday, February 27th, Randolph-Henry High School hosted guest speaker Ms. Angela Cook. She started off the assembly with getting students into groups and having them work together to complete a puzzle. Then she spoke about abolitionist and political activist Harriet Tubman and her efforts to free as many people from slavery as possible. Students were eager to answer trivia questions about Harriet Tubman and learn more about her. People who attended the assembly learned that Harriet Tubman had led over 70 people to freedom through the Underground Railroad. Ms. Angela Cook then explained the purpose of the puzzle activity that the students participated in. She wanted us to think about ourselves as puzzle pieces. She said that we are unique, and we should always be ourselves, because someone needs our skills and qualities to fit into their puzzle. “The whole world is a puzzle. Someone in this world needs you. You are someone’s puzzle piece,” said Cook.
By Lily Woodfin

On February 25, 2020, Randolph-Henry High school held their second Interactive Enrichment assembly in celebration of Black History Month. They hosted guest speaker William McCargo. He spoke about the difficult journey that African-Americans have had to endure throughout history from slavery, to segregation in schools. McCargo showed a video mentioning the different schools in Virginia that started the Massive Resistance to the desegregation laws passed in the 20th century, and explaining how it was resolved by Supreme Court cases such as Brown vs. Board of Education. He encouraged the students to do more research about Black History Month and other cases that contributed to these equal rights movements. “If you won’t fix the problem, you are part of the problem,” said McCargo. The assembly was ended with a Black History Month trivia game. Three different questions were asked, and the students in the audience who answered correctly received a prize from McCargo himself.
-Lily Woodfin

He encouraged the students to do more research about Black History Month and other cases that contributed to these equal rights movements. “If you won’t fix the problem, you are part of the problem,” said McCargo. The assembly was ended with a Black History Month trivia game. Three different questions were asked, and the students in the audience who answered correctly received a prize from McCargo himself.
-Lily Woodfin

On Saturday, November 23, 2019, several CCPS teachers returned back to college for the day as they visited the campus of Longwood University!

Longwood University Alumni and Career Services hosted a "We Teach to Enlighten Summit” professional development brunch for alumni educators and their guests to (re)connect with other Longwood Alumni Educators around the Commonwealth of Virginia. CCPS Longwood Alumni in attendance included Robin Mason (Eureka), Elisabeth Toombs (Randolph-Henry), and Kari Joyner (Randolph-Henry). Laura Graves and Monique Williams, both of Randolph-Henry, were invited guests who enjoyed touring and learning more about Longwood’s post-graduate programs and career services. The general session and roundtable discussions sparked conversations on the Five C's of Education and career readiness for Virginia’s graduates.

On November 14, 2019, Randolph-Henry High School students were visited by two guest speakers during their enrichment period. Each Tuesday and Thursday, students can opt to receive remediation in a class or participate in enrichment in the auditorium. Magen Powell, the Director of Operations at Broad Highway Recovery and David Sorenson, a member of the Piedmont Alliance for the Prevention of Substance Abuse delivered powerful messages to students about the dangers of drug and alcohol addiction. Following the program, students were allowed to thank our guests
and ask specific questions.

Pictured below: Randolph-Henry student Madison Dewberry, guest speaker Magen Powell, Randolph-Henry student Brianna Estep, and guest speaker David Sorenson.
